question:
You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code generated is executable for display when possible. Continue with HTML to create a patrol plan:

Select patrol route: Choose from preset routes or customize your own route.

Set patrol time: Select start and end times.

Assign patrol personnel: Select patrol officers from the personnel list.

Save plan: Click the "Save" button to activate the plan.

Edit patrol plan: Select an existing plan, modify the route, time, or personnel, then click "Save."

Delete patrol plan: Select a plan and click "Delete."

View plan list: Display all patrol plans with filtering options by date, route, and personnel.

checklist.title: Is the patrol route selection functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Check if the code includes both preset route selection and custom route creation capabilities. The interface should display route options visually (e.g., on a map or as a list) and allow for interactive selection. For custom routes, verify if waypoint creation, modification, and deletion are supported. Score 0 if route selection is missing, 5 if only preset routes are available, and 10 if both preset and fully functional custom route creation are implemented.

checklist.title: Are patrol time settings properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate if the time selection interface provides intuitive date and time pickers for both start and end times. Check if the implementation validates time inputs (preventing end time before start time), handles time zones appropriately, and offers recurring schedule options. Verify if the interface shows visual feedback for selected time periods. Score 0 if time settings are missing, 5 if basic time selection exists but lacks validation, and 10 if time selection is complete with validation and visual indicators.

checklist.title: Is personnel assignment functionality complete?
checklist.description: Review whether the personnel selection interface displays staff availability, shows qualification badges/ratings, and prevents scheduling conflicts. Check if the implementation allows multi-selection of patrol officers and displays their work hours/schedule conflicts. Verify if capacity planning (minimum/maximum officers per patrol) is enforced. Score 0 if personnel assignment is missing, 5 if basic selection exists without conflict checking, and 10 if it's fully implemented with availability checks and qualification filtering.

checklist.title: Are plan management operations (save, edit, delete) properly implemented?
checklist.description: Test if the save, edit, and delete operations are correctly implemented with proper confirmation dialogs, undo capabilities, and data validation. Check if edited plans maintain their historical records and if deletion includes archiving options. Verify if the system prevents deletion of active patrols without supervisor confirmation. Score 0 if these operations are missing, 5 if they exist but lack validation or confirmation features, and 10 if they're fully implemented with all safety measures.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as invalid inputs, network interruptions, concurrent edits, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Real-time GPS tracking integration 2. Weather overlay on patrol routes 3. Mobile notifications for patrol officers 4. AI-suggested optimal patrol routes based on historical incident data). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple ways to select personnel with inconsistent UIs) 2. Function modules unrelated to patrol planning (e.g., an embedded social media feed) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations that slow down the interface). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data/service/view layers), component reusability, and responsive design implementation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the code doesn't adapt to different screen sizes. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Click feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition animation duration controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual focus guidance. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for visual after-images during fast sliding, and 5 points for hard-to-find key function buttons. The full score is 10 points.
